text: Tap at Cosmic Comic Cafe. Clear golden color, small white head and lace. Light grainy and fruity nose. Light-bodied. Grainy, grassy, a bit buttery, very Bohemian. Well-brewed.

Golden colour with a mediumsized white foamy head. Aroma is earth, some grains, grass and mild sweet and bready malts to it. Flavour is grassy, hayish, some floral and mild grainy and bready notes.
1/2 pint on tap @ One Pint Pub. Pours clear golden with a medium head. Aroma is clean malts with some fresh hops. Flavor is bitter malts with a crisp hoppyness. Almost too hoppy. Almost. Nice.

Tap @ One pint pub. 
Pours clear golden with a thick white head. 
Earthy, slightly buttery and rubbery aroma. Grassy as well. 
Flavor has grass, wet hay, earth, hops, floral notes.

5%ABV. czech pilsner.

Poured out light gold. 5ºSRM.

Mouthfeel is light soap. Palate has a beautiful floral character with jasmine being most prominent, there is a hint of chrysantehmums as well. Malty palate is soda biscuits, water crackers, Hops are floral, then vanishing into a long thin sappy resinous bitter.

Overall a floral hoppy Pilsner.

Goes on Favorites List!
Taste was quite pleasant, but the aroma was subtle to the point of homeopathy. Refreshing with trout for dinner, and definitely didnt overpower the fish.

Tuatara Pilsner.
Dorata pallida, limpida, schiuma bianca fine e di ottima persistenza.
Aroma agrumato molto volatile, note di ananas molto leggere, erbaceo, pepe, malto d'orzo e note metalliche.
Al palato decisamente amara, attacca con malto d'orzo note di ananas e note citriche, finale amaro erbaceo e resinoso di pompelmo.
Molto carbonata, corpo medio-leggero.

Tap @ Konttori.
Pours clear pale golden color with a large white head. Aroma is grassy hoppy, somewhat citric, a bit herbal too. Harsh grassy bitterness on the flavor, citrus, gooseberries. Refreshing but a bit too harsh. 
4214

As Pilsner. Clear light gold with a thick head of foam. The aroma is incredibly perfumey with grape notes, possibly hopped with Nelson Sauvin?

Crackery malts, ash and floral hops on a crisp light body. Possibly past its best as it was on sale but once was enough. Surprisingly grassy and bitter.

Bottle. Hazy straw coloured, with white, frothy well retained head. Great lacing. Very gentle lemon blossom and grass hops aromas, with a hint of honey malt. Great bitterness throughout palate, combining grass, spicy and citrus hops and an ever so slight sweet honey and bread malt background. Long, bitter, spicy finish. Refreshing, crisp, clean. Very good pils. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Golden color, clear liquid, white head. Taste is rather too bitter for Czech pilsner. Aroma is on the hops side. Unpleasant vomit smell, but quite good beer though.

330ml bottle
Pale straw color with good head.
Aroma is grassy/citrus.
Mild bitterness with crisp finish - a good session beer for a hot summer day.

330ml bottle. Crystal clear, yellow-ish, pale golden colour with average to huge, thick, fluffy, mostly lasting, moderately lacing, white head. Minimally soapy, floral hoppy and husky, malty spicy aroma, yeasty doughy undertones. Taste is malty spicy, slightly doughy yeasty, floral hoppy overtones; soft and smooth, clean palate.
330ml Bottle. Pours a very light and hazy gold with lots of white head. A subtle bitterness with clean hop flavours coming through.

330ml bottle. Aroma is grass, peach and melon. Flavour is funky grass, lots of peach and apricot into a bitter finish. Certainly not my favourite style, but by far the best NZ example of it. Crisp, fruity and easy to drink. If Im in the mood for something lager then this is what Id go for every time.
Not a huge nose on this beer, but then on tasting was pleasantly surprised by the lovely hoppy profile from the NZ hop focus. Good length, great fresh pallet. lovely beer!

330ml bottle into glass. Manky, earthy, grassy nose. Pale yellow beer with thin white head. A few bubbles. Zingy taste and YES, grainy pilsener notes. Interesting take, like a pils with over-ripe fruit and dry earth. Dry finish lingers.
This is ace - great body, a twist on the Czech style with some fruity notes, clean, compact. Just a really well made, flavourful beer.

Bottle from World Beer Market (Sake no Taniguchi). Pale malt aroma, bread, light citrus. Clear very plae starw color, with little cirrus cloud filmy head. Malty initial, sweetish jump in mid palate, hops emerges slowly and then hit stronger in finish. Thin-medium body. Not bad. The mild sweet jump in mid palate is interesting.
Pale yellow pour with a huge fluffy white head. Malt and a fair whack of lemon on the nose. Taste is crisp, malty, a good bit of hoppy bitterness in there too

Textbook pilsner pour with huge white head and yellow body, no carbonation, slight fog. Soft lemon aroma, some nut. Flavour is nondeScript, crisp and smooth and goes down easy like all the beer commercials say. But I cant pick out anything. Good to drink if you dont like drinking, I guess.

Bottle. Unripped peach, grapefruit peel, hint of candy. Nice citrus bite, lime zest, mikan crisp body, bready notes, dry finish. Pretty solid, almost as good as it gets for a pilsner, could easily down kegs of that :)
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy grassy aroma. Fruity malty grainy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy finish.
Bottle from Drink? Hebden Bridge. Paler golden coloured with a thin head. Lightly fruit hopped, there is some flavour in this ale-like pilsner! Has a few malts too.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Hotel, Bangkok. Golden beer with a strong frothy white head. The aroma is yeasty and dry, and the flavour is very dry with bitterness and yeastiness. Overall a nice Pilsner style beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Clear orange appearance with a small head. Fresh sweet flavour with a slightly bitter finish. Left lots of lacing. A good one.

Draught @ Beer Deluxe, Melbourne.
Pale straw good clarity.
Nice but subtle nose - floral hops, touch of grass & savoury spice, with cereally malts beneath.
Light bodied, crisp.
Flavours are clean and easy - cracker biscuit, grainy pilsner malts, herbaceous, slightly fruit hops lend a moderate bitterness.
Well made, enjoyable.

330ml bottle from The Wine Seller, Wolverhampton. Pours clear gold, white head. Light malt aroma. Taste bears a sharp bitterness at the fore with a subtle sweet malt character. An odd hop presence thats hard to put my finger on. A tad disjointed perhaps.

Wow, surprisingly good. Nice slatey szaz hoppiness, but also a little of the fruitiness that youd expect from new world hops. Creamy fizzy mouthfeel. A little cloudy. Not too much aroma. VERY bitter for a lager.
Pale gold. Great aroma, floral and fruity. Flavour is a bit less intense but the pale malt comes through well.

Bottle. This was a taste for sore taste buds after a run of ticks so bad I was almost ready to throw in my two-ounce taster glass and give up on ticking beer. Fun fact: the heart is called the "ticker" because losing your will to tick is akin to losing your will to live. So this one... Really nice golden pour with a small white head. Grassy and floral aroma. Balanced flavor, dry and hoppy, with a great grassy clean finish. Medium light and very drinkable, well carbonated. I like this one!

Aroma: floral hops, intense grain malts, bread, caramel and straw. Appearance: clear gold, medium, frothy, white head. Taste: medium bitter. Palate: floral hops, bitters intensify, dry finish, pale malts. Overall: nice Pilsner, intense malts infused with lots of hops. Bottle from Twenty One Wines, Brighton.

2nd July 2015Very light haze on this gold beer, thin white head. Palate is semi dry and only has moderate carbonation. Dry pale malts, soem bread. Modest floral bitterness. The malts come back with some cream before a bitter floral finish. Mild bitter linger. So what hops are in this Pils? Saaz or Motueka, Nelson and Riwaka? Says both in the beers listing description. Tastes more like Saaz. Slightly disappointing overall, could be crisper and lighter and would have been very interesting with those NZ hops,

Bottle from Drinkmonger. Clear golden body with a thick white head. Steady carbonation. Light lacing. Aroma of herbs, spicy hops, pineapple skin and lemon. Flavour of grain, lemony hops and grass. Medium body with a light, oily texture. Crisp fizz. Lean and hoppy. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2015 (330ml bottle, Beijing) Appearance: medium straw yellow, a bit darker yellow than your typical lager. Nice billowy, white head with some irregularities. Decent amount of foam. Head dissipates to islands of clinginess and tracing. Nose: Really smell the hops. Floral, green, herbaceous, some citrus/berry. Taste: fruity upfront with a good bitter follow-thru. Citrus peel, roasted malt, tobacco. 
Palate: Refreshing, cleansing, bright ... then long lasting bitterness and lingering grass/tree/herb flavors on the cheeks. Overall: different than your typical pilsner, almost a bit IPA-ish because of the hoppiness and grapefruit. I like it ... a beer you can chew, digest and talk about ... a clean beer with both malt and hop characteristics. 

High points: hops, chewinesss, uniqueness
Low points: might be too bitter for some, with the hops overpowering the malt flavors (especially if expecting a typical lager/pilsner)

Clear light copper (like apple juice). Thin white head with big bubbles. Smells of hop, cereal, pepper/clove. Taste is bitter hop, light spice, cereal/grain malt, lemon and lightly floral finish. Body is slick, medium, dry finish, very little carbonation. Pils flavours (present but not heavy) + hop + more malt than I expected.
An excellent local brew that suffers only in having some serious competition in the space. Similar to Panheads rather than Emersons brew but not as nice a finish.
Keg at the Hanging Bat. Pours clear pale gold with a thin white head. Aromas of cooked corn, fresh sweat. Taste is lightly astringent, bitter lemon, hint of lime. Dry finish.
On tap at Pour House. Pours a golden color with a bit of head. Nice hop profile. Prominent but not overpowering the malt.
Tap at ivy&lolas, queenstown nz. Clear golden color, white head. Aroma is malty, fresh and hoppy. Crispy dry hoppy taste, malty, fresh.
Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. Very pale straw coloured with a malty and bitter grassy flavour, gentle floral fruity flavours followed by a very dry bitter grapefruit finish.

330ml bottle from Good Spirits Co, Glasgow (£2.60):
Quite a nice pilsner, one that was clean and very easy to drink with a nice bitterness throughout and plenty of citrus flavours too. There was more hops than I had been expecting from the style but it was a nice surprise that helped the beer down even easier than otherwise might have been the case. Good stuff from Tuatata and a decent pilsner that I wouldnt mind picking up again.
I reckon one the best new style Pilsners out there....simple as that!......but, dare the new Brewers to have a crack at this style as there are no bushes to hide behind........;-)

Pours an ever so slightly hazy golden color with fluffy, lasting, white head. Aroma is classic pils with a spicy hop & yeast, and sharp pils malt backbone. Flavor is clean and crisp with a mild sulfur note.
Pretty hoppy for a pilsner. Pours light yellow, little head. Aroma and taste of hops, yeasts, and wheat.

On keg at the Bow Bar Winter Beer Festival. 
Appearance - golden with a very thin head. 
Nose - slightly peach then Saaz spice. 
Taste - dry clean malt and metallic and dry herbs. 
Palate - light bodied with a lean tight structure and a long dry finish. 
Overall - good palate.

Bottle at Brew, Thonglor, Bangkok. Poured a light hazy straw colour with a big frothy white head. The aroma is dry mineral yeast. The flavour is moderate bitter with a dry crisp yeast hop bitter palate. Light bodied with average carbonation. Not a great beer but a good Pilsner.
Keg at the hanging bat.. Golden yellow... Sweet fruits.. Light.. Grassy... Nose.. Yearg grassy fruits
UPDATED: APR 1, 2015 Keg at the hanging bat. Pours clear golden, nose is grassy, toffee, herbal, taste is sweet toffee, herbal.
Bottle. Clear, golden, frothy, white foam, medium bitterness, light sweetness, light body, oily feel, soft carbonation, & bitter finish.

Purchased at Parker Pie. $5.50 for the 12 oz. bottle. Pours a straw-colored cloudy dark yellow with which an off-white head 1 and half fingers in length stood (I asked for a pint from the tender). Tastes and smells of white grapes, sunflower seeds, pilsner malt, LME, asparagus, and German yeast. Clean, floral, and heavier than expected.
Great fresh, crisp pilsner. One of my favourite kiwi pils, close to a czech pils. Nice aroma too.
styly 500ml bottle pours pale & frothy, aroma is all hops, taste is bitter malty hoppy & lingering, all works really well
Strong noble earthy and grass led hops. Sharp crisp finish. Soft grain notes. Quite a nice pils. More please.

Bottle at Hamilton during reunion. Pours hazy gold with a creamy, white head. The nose has crackers malts, light caramel, citrus essence. Medium sweet flavor with some pale bread, lightly faded hops, hay, grains, biscuits. Light bodied with average carbonation. Mostly sweet on the finish with further crackers sweetness, some grassy bitternesss, light orange. Simple and tasty enough.

Aroma is roasty malts, citrus, grapefruit and slight lemon grass. Taste is sweet malt followed quickly by a earthy, citrus rich hop. Fairly strange character for a pilsner. Body is a pale gold with a thin pearl head that retains fairly poorly.

Pale yellow colour with a small white head that dissipates quickly. Very floral and sweet aromas with some lemon and grassy notes. Also has the pilsener yeast aromas. Soft but effective hop usage with an excellent malt backbone. Coming from someone who doesnt usually like pilseners, I enjoyed this. Probably the best pilsener Ive tried
Bottle at Phukets. Crisp hoppy flavor. Pilsner aroma. Bitter dry finish. Good for a pilsner, very easy drinking.
Crystal clear golden colour. Grassy fruity notes. Clean crisp taste; beautiful tasteful malt finished well with just the right amount of hops. Bittersweet aftertaste makes you want more.

12oz bottle at Restaurant Public in SoHo, NYC. Pours a clear gold with some thin white head. Nose is fine enough, lightly sweet, crackery, grass, lemon, a little butter, some cardboard too. Flavor is fine, definitely has a Pacific twist, some sweetness, some cardboard, a little lime, some honey, a little jasmine, almost a little rice. Clean finish.
Bottle from Aeon. Nice aroma, grassy hops, hint of lemon. Taste is good, crisp and pretty bitter. Little bit of malty sweetness in there, but focus is the hops. Good stuff.
Slightly hazy golden. Thin white head. Bitter malty aroma. Nice bitter.taste with a healthy malt backbone. Good session beer.

(Bottle) Clear pale gold with reasonable white head. Nice citrus / lemon hoppy aroma. Light body, excellent bright carbonation. Refreshing tangy citrus foretaste with nice candy sweet undercurrent, then some lovely hops assert their bitterness for a long finish. Excellent pilsner.

12 oz. bottle from Beer Rev. It pours a hazy yellow color with a nice white head. I didnt check for any bottle dates on this one, and Im kind of regretting it upon sniffing it. Its not bad, just not very crisp theres some strong toffee sweetness along with some citrus and florals that make for a pretty good balance, but not at all pilsener-like. The flavor is creamy and bitter with nice notes of melon, citrus, toffee, honeysuckle and a floral bitterness in the finish. A decent and rather interesting Pilsener, but Im thinking this was a little past its prime.

330 ml brown reptilian bottle purchased in Wellington, NZ. 
Pours amber with a bubbly head. 
A bold and hoppy pilsner featuring NZ hops, with an aromatic herbal nose but with the hop power of an American pale ale. Long lasting hoppy aftertaste with more hop complexity than usual. Appropriate malts for balance mainly appear as a limitation on bitterness. 
Feel: medium body; nice crisp carbonation. 
O: a good pils.

Bottle. Oily lemon, musty cheese, dried grass and herb hops with baked cracker and toast pale malt character. Its a clean aroma, and more interesting than their other products, doesnt show off the green onion or chemical cleaner aroma found in many NZ-hopped beers. Tingly washing of acid across the tongue is quenching and satisfying. Light body, off-dry, medium bitterness, everything in balance. Easily the best thing Ive had from Tuatara and the only one I found flavorful enough to drink an entire portion.
One of the best NZ beers Ive ever tasted - and Ive tasted a few over the decades. It is crisp and clean and Im going to be drinking it all summer Im sure

330 ml bottle bought at YATA in Grand Century Place, Mong Kok.
Appearance: Clear, light dull golden colour with thin trace of yeast particles; two finger head and lasting crumpety white foam stays on top throughout this session. Excellent sticky lacing with very fizzy carbonation.

Aroma: Very fragrant full malt, with IPA- like fresh grapefruit, passion fruit, mango, honey, canned fruits, pine, bread and faint grass.

Taste: Medium sweet full lager malt, with passion fruit, grapefruit, citrus, molasses, pine, bread, light yeast, liquorices, strong lime and grass.

Body: Full body, thick and oily palate.

Mouth Feel: All malt with full on NZ hoppy attack - refreshing passion fruits, grapefruit zest, nice citrus, and hop oilyness. Yummy! Fat maltiness and bready. Sweetness is strong but is nicely-balanced by sharp liquorices and herbal hops. At times this tastes more like a full on IPA! Wow!

Hoppiness: Very fragrant tropical fruits, grapefruits, pine and lime in nose and taste, hop-oily palate, and a sharp Czech-Pils like bitterness for a nice and lasting finishing.

After Taste: Dry, fruity and nicely bitter to mouth.

Comments: Call it a bastard Czech Pils if you like, but I really dig the brewers creativity and innovation to freshen up a traditional type with all these NZ hops. The result is fully on tropical fruitiness and thickness, while preserving the goodness of Czech Pils richness and astringency. Enjoyable from start to finish. Simply excellent!.

Cloudy soda pop with a skunky aroma,very little head.
Taste was spot on among the best CZ pilsners.
Low ratings due to a beer that sat in this vendors cooler forever.
Probably the last time I shop at this disrespectful vendor...
500ml bottle. A fine handcrafted pilsner with decent grassy Saaz hop bitterness and dry finish. Pours translucent bright golden with fluffy white head. Medium body and crisp refreshing mouthfeel.

pours hazy pale yellow with a small white cap, some retention and lacing. shy maltiness, white grape juice, if not a wineyness for kiwi hops, some soapy, citrus and floral notes, restrained spiciness - some pepper. average carbonation, light body - oily, relatively dry but not so crisp peppery-citrusy finish. quaffable but lacking in many points.

Bottle from Coop from the Tuatara Mix 6 (2 of 6). Pours a clear yellow colour, nice white foam, medium retention. Aroma is pleasant, generously hopped - saaz style, very true to a czech pils.. Mouthfeel is bubbly and crisp, medium carbonation. Taste is hint of sweet malt, dries out in the fairly smooth finish with a nice hoppy presence. Delicious.

330mL thanks to Travlr fresh from NZ! Pours a clear straw to gold. Medium foam. Nose is raw grain, candy corn. Taste is quite awesome though- snappy and crisp grain, mild lemon, mild soap. Rustic, sourdough crust, grapefruit rind in mouthfeel. Really improves into something great.

My Bottom Line:
Lax bready malts and bitter hop spiciness ride this brews unrefined mouthfeel.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sheet of foam tops the cloudy beige blond.
-Carbonation is quite high, which in this case seems to increase the level of roughness.
-The aroma is timid without any clear hop or malt expression.
-A touch of diacetyl seems to be tied to the flavor profile.
-This bottle was flabby at best; no brightness at all, no crispness either. Definitely tastes like its past its best, but how was I supposed to tell without a date to be found on the bottle?

Bottle.
Draft at House. Clear golden color, thick white head with good retention and solid lacing. Aroma of fruity whitenpepper. Taste is similar.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2015 Bottle from Plonk. Clear yellow/amber, lasting tight head, citrusy/grassy hops, nice malt flavour, very well balanced, clean and crisp. Very nice.
Re-rate April 2015 - bumped up rating, a very underrated pilsener.
From what I remember this was a standard pilsner. Clear, refreshing but nothing more really. Went well with the superb fish dish I was having at the time.

Bottle from mane liquor. Pale yellow pour with a small white head. Nice light citrus and sweet malts in the aroma. Taste is much the same nice citrus hoppy presence. So easy on the palate. Perfect session beer 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pale yellow.  Mostly fruity aroma. Citrus and moderate bitterness, and with light pale malts.  Heavier, wetter finish like damp grass is a bit ale-like.

Best pilsner I have tasted brewed here in NZ, so far. Have tried this brew  before, and  chose it again, as lately I have been disappointed with some other pilsners I have tried that have been brewed overseas (eg Samuel Adams Noble Pils). I love the grassiness of the saaz hops and the slight citrus flavour of this drop. It is a very refreshing well engineered beer.Nice.

Whole Foods, Bowery 33cl ($4): Pours orange color with a frothy white head. Aroma is a bit of sugar, grass, yeast, and something akin to bread. Taste is quite nice. Nice amount of bitterness throughout. A few particular soda-ish type notes. Some minor sweetness. Very crisp and smooth. Some minor complexity.

Poured out a lightly hazy bright white yellow gold, medium sized white cap. Warm cereal malts, sweet green gummy candy, lemon zest, mild spice, touch of citrus, nice thick fragrance. Every sip is highly enjoyable. Malty and hopped pretty heavily. More cereal malts that really carry the taste well, long mellow spice and some zip, mellow citrus has died off and given way to the spice. Leaves a dry mouth. Really good stuff!
Best by is in 2010. Now it is a tart and yeasty brew with a sharp, sparkling carbonation.

The best Tuatara in my opinion.
Its amazing how they can pack so much deliciousness into this lager, yet still come across as so uncomplicated, with a short clean finish. Just how I like my lager. Im drinking another as I write this and, honestly, as the good feeling sinks in Im tempted to rate it higher and higher (baby).
Almost non-existent aroma - classic pilsner. Light peach appearance. Bitter hops comes through on the flavour; very refreshing. Palate, wrecked.

In your face pilsner that deserves the accolades that have been bestowed on this refreshing drop.  Marmalade bitterness with a lingering palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location: 11.2 oz bottle from State Line, 2/11/13, Rating #2828, so nice I type it twice


Aroma: The nose is a little grassy, with some lemon zest, bready malts, and floral notes

Appearance: Pours a cloudy gold-orange with a rather large froth of white head and plenty of lace

Flavor: Tastes a little sweet, with some clean pale malts, bread, and a grassy/floral hop bitterness

Palate: The body is light-medium, it drinks kinda clean, with lively carbonation, and a light dryness

Overall Impression: 
This one is a solid Pils, but it isnt crisp and clean enough to be a top example of what I really look for in this style.  Still though, theres some nice stuff here and the malts and the hops work well together.

(330ml bottle) Mixed Tuatara 6-pack from Cook Street Liquor for $22. Pours a medium, white head atop a clear lightly carbonated head. Mild corn aroma. Good crispness and hoppy front , very chewy and grainy. I like this.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPod

Pours a golden yellow with a healthy white head that leaves some lace. Aromas of pale malt/straw, floral and clean. Flavours consist of spicy sazz bitterness with a crisp malty complexity. Quite refreshing.
Clean, crisp - nice floral nose, but a bit hidden - possibly from the distance/age of the bottle.  Still had some nice subtleties to it.

Every bit as good, or better, than a can of Urquel today. Crisp gold, thin head and faint lace. Light grassy hop aroma. Flavour was a nice up front hopiness, only slightly aggresive. Hops are present from start to stronger finish. Nice body and an easy drinker. Be easy to quaff a 6er.

Poured a clear golden amber colour with a one-finger white foamy head that retained OK and laced OK. High carbonation (lots of fine bubble trails). Aroma of hops with a hint of lemon. Taste clean and crisp followed by hops bitterness and a slight citrus flavour. Medium to ligh body. Moderately long slightly bitter finish. More like a Pale Ale.

A delightfully quaffable devil of a brew this one turned out to be and yet another tick on the board of lagers coming out of the micros of NZ at the moment. It produced up a satin sheened, yellow gold, just off bright, with high effervescence and a compact, tight white crown. Juicy, fruity burst wafts from the glass reminiscent of passionfruit, pineapple, lychee and sauvignon wine with underlying notes of pine needs, black pepper and rose petals. Soft, creamy mouthfeel with just a little spritz upfront. Light, well rounded and wonderfully hoppy throughout with just enough malt flavour to let its presence known. Spicy, floral, herbal and piney backend with a lasting bitterness to the swallow. Juicy fruit esters, like in the aroma, are the star here though. It is notably vinous with a quenching citrus tang and sourness, and supple passion/pine/lychee blend that linger long in amongst the herbal and floral hops. These Motueka Saaz hops are fantastic and this beer brilliantly showcases them. I loved this one. Everything works so harmoniously. This is one to definitely hunt down again. A killer of a Summer Pilsener!!! (33cL, BB 20/09/12, Freo Doctor, Fremantle)

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2013 Too good to be just Saaz hops. Such a fruity, grapey, aroma, true dessert wine. Really Saaz? Hard to believe. But do not mistake me: the beer is fabulous! Looks great, light, lemoney gold with a decent white head, almost creamy. Crisp and bitter, hoppy, fruity and floral, all balanced by a very light touch of maltiness that never makes it mellow. It is bitter, and bloody pleasant! The finish is a bit acidic, metallic, but im being too hard on this great beer. Not a perfect Bohemiam Pilsener, but better!

Nice, fresh straw aroma with some daisies and blackberries in there... hm Ive got a terrible memory but I swear this was the first time Ive seen solid webs down the side of the glass with a Czech Pils. Must be a NZ thing. Recommended as a beer many will like, pale lager guys and geeks included.

Bottle at home. Pours pale with a thick, persistent head. Great hop aroma with floral and citrus notes. Incredible hop bitterness defines the taste. The body is very light with rather low carbonation. Very lingering bitter finish. One of the best (and most bitter) pilsner I have tasted.

330ml brown bottle. Bright gold pour, clear, fat and creamy white cap that lasts a long time. Aromas of grain and straw. Taste has clean malts, straw. Finishes with straw and big grassy hop notes, light bitterness. Light bodied, good crisp carbonation. Overall a good beer, nothing fancy or complex,  just a decent easy to drink pils.
Pours a clear straw color. Aroma is straw, malt. Taft is similar. Not a great beer.

Bottle. Every bit as good, or better, than a can of Urquel today. Crisp gold, thin head and faint lace. Light grassy hop aroma. Flavour was a nice up front hopiness, only slightly aggresive. Hops are present from start to stronger finish. Nice body and an easy drinker. Be easy to quaff a 6er.

Bottle with no indicated freshness date and a high fill line. Pours with a lightly hazed (unfiltered/bottle conditioned) golden yellow hued body with a large, fluffy and decently retentive white head. Lace is average. Aromas of hops. Lemony, grassy, light lime, a touch of mint and thai basil.  Floral. Fresh and raw, inviting, sweet malt character. Clean fermentation wise. Very grassy, light resin. Flavors are of lemon, lemon verbena, grainy (almost wheat like malt presence). Lots of citrus zest, light tea and mango. Lightly grassy hop. Good balance. Lightly bitter balance, very clean bitterness! No esters. Lively carbonation. Dry, clean, somewhat crisp. Light bodied. Good beer.

Soft aromas of floral hops, lemon, and some bread/oats. Pours a light gold with a puffy cream white foam top. Smooth taste with flavors of bread, yeast, biscuit, barley, oats and some moderate bittering hops. Thin in texture with a subtle carbination. Overall, as far as my experience with pilsners go, this is above average. Very smooth and crisp taste, strong drinkability. Id give this a B rating.
In my opinion the best pilsner in NZ at the moment. This has improved immensely in the last couple of years.
This is by far the best craft pilsner out of NZ.  It delivers the ability to refresh whilst still being cerebral enough to keep hop-heads happy.

Bottle.
Aroma: Earthy, floral and piney hop, orange malt roasted grain
Palate: Starts with rounded mouth feel that becomes dry and bitter on the finish.
Flavor: Crisp, dried orange, roasted grain, earthy and piney hop flavors.  Firm but pleasing bitterness on the finish.
Comments: Fun to contrast this bigger (maltier and with more bittering) style to the Emersons.  Both are fine pilsners.

330ml bottle: Pours hazy, almost cloudy gold with a white head which lingers and laces the glass. Light zesty malts on the nose, medium hopped. Nice balance of bitterness and sweetness, smooth finish. Very sessionable this one.

330ml bottle pours a hazy pale golden color with a 2 finger white head with great retention and leaving a thin lacing on the glass.  Aroma is grassy with some earthy hops and citrus.  Taste is malty sweetness balanced with a generous earthy hop bitterness and citrus.  Medium body and generous carbonation leave a nice touch on the palate.  This is a pleasant pilsner which is uniquely its own and quite enjoyable.

Bottle via sloth.  I am uncertain as to why he sent this to me other than to be an annoying Merlunder. Moderately hazy cider looking in the glass. Thin spotty head.  Hoppy and bitter finish.  Thin singular body.  The only thing that stands apart from boring is the finish.  As Bert would say..."meh".

Bottle from AD. Medium brownish gold with a thin head. Aroma is floral hop with an earthy background. Flavour is fruity hop with a mellow white wine texture and feel. Finish is sharp bitter, refreshing.

This beer is a little difficult for me to rate as its very good, very fresh, and as much as I like hops, maybe they overdid the hop in this. Served at a good temperature and poured a large, foamy, frothy, off-white head that settles out after a bit and plenty of lace. Color is a crystal clear yellow gold with a number of small bubble trails. Aroma is hop, malt, grain, grass. Flavor is like nose, with good balance to the carbonic tang; fairly dry. Body is good although, for a Czech Pils, the hops do clash a bit with the carbonation a bit in contrast to the true Czech smoothness. Finish is like flavor, fairly long and very drinkable.

Features a great buttery bread malt aroma with a touch of hops. No skunk at all. Hazy yellow colored, looks unfiltered like a hefe. Pronounced bitter front with some sweet citrus notes. Dry, grainy finish. Not what one expects from a classic pils. Solid offering, though the price makes it a one bottle novelty sampler in the US. Imported by Shelton Brothers.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2012 330 ml bottle. Great golden colour on a summers day about to have a nice pizza. Faint hoppy and malt aroma. Hardly any head but thats ok, there are a few bubbles rising to the top. Fresh clean hoppy taste. Smooth balanced malty flavour with fantastic bitterness coming through and lingering. Awesome Sunday afternoon drink in the sun.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Fantastic clear amber pour with a big, fluffy white head. Aroma is all zest and spices with a touch of doughy malts in the background. Taste is very buttery and citric. Loads of lemon zest with a touch of buttered biscuit and doughy bread. Bitter finish turns to a dry lengthy finish on the palate. Very good pils

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2012 Consider this beer a good gateway beer to better things.  Not overly hoppy, but enough for people to get a taste of what a good pilsner should taste like.

Very quaffable.
Moderate hoppy. Huge, frothy, white head. Good lacing. Mostly lasting longevity. Clear, light yellow body. Heavy bitter and very hoppy flavor. Medium palate.

11.2oz bottle, no date from College Liquors in Grand Junction. Hazy light golden with a one finger white head, fair retention.  Biscuit malts and yeast dominate the nose, hints of grass at the end with a tinge of lemon--mainly biscuity though. Flavor adds some old dusty malt, but the biscuit still dominates.  This may have a bit of age on it, as Im having trouble with any hops here. Dry finish, bitterness peaked at a 4-5.  Lowish creamy carbonation with a light body.  If this wasnt $5 a bottle, Im sure itd move off the shelves more quickly (and in effect be tastier)--kinda like Mikkellers $6 pils.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: An altogether perfect pilsner, and has been a regular in the fridge this spring. Nice lightly-hopped crisp citrus aroma, hazy in the glass and remaining cloudy with a nice head. The flavour has a beautiful balance with fruity citrus hops up against nice outdoorsy grassiness. Would choose their APA over this any day, but this is a nice compromise now the APA not available for a while.

The colour was pale amber brown, and there was a medium creamy white head with medium carbonation. There was a crisp citrus bitter aroma and a smooth malt fruit taste with a medium bitter hoppy finish. This is a pleasant clean crisp style with light fruit balance, and medium body.

33 cl bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a huge white head. Crisp citrusy to grassy hoppy aroma, light whitewine touch. Fruity, citrusy and whitewine hops flavoured. Solid bitterness going into a rather dry and bitter finish.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, hay. Flavour is fruit, malt, hay, grain. Medium body. OK beer.

12oz ticketty-boo bottle from Premier Gourmet.  Pours slightly hazy light gold with a large fizzy-foamy white head (3+).  Smells quite pleasant - heather, honey, very light grain and slightly pungent grassiness to mellow out the sweetness - quite clean.  Taste - a bit metallic, sadly, but grassy and no corn, booze, weeds, poop, anti-freeze or any other detractors - and frankly the "metal" was gone in a flash, leaving me to think it might have been my palate adjusting to a surprising amount of pungent grassy hop bitterness - pretty solid, actually - and all the way from NZ?  Average body, crisply carbonated, starts a tad sweet, but finishes dry with a hint of bitter astringency ... if the LCBO were to stock sixers of this at a reasonable price, I would buy it - frankly it is better than the Sam Adams Noble Pils, which I am finding too sweet now.

Noble fragrant perfumy slightly citrusy spicy hop aroma, with underlay of sweet pilsner malt. med to high body, sweet malt again, brisk spicy bitterness, slight hoppy aftertaste. Good solid pilsner, spot on to the style

Bottle 330ml.Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, toasted, moderate hoppy, citrus, grass, dusty, plastic notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, sharp. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110416]

Bottle 330ml @ fonefan
Pours hazy golden with awhite head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and caramel. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
Bottle @ Ulfborg Easter Tasting, 2011. Pours hazy yellow with a off white head. Grassy and dry flavor. Bit of bread - buiscuit. Smooth. Medium bodied.

Bottle. A clear, golden beer with a small, white head. Quite pleasant aroma with sugary fruityness and some pale malts. Quite sweet flavor, fruity and with some bitterness. Medium body, decent carbonation. A pretty straight forward pilsner but too sweet. Rather boring actually. 110416
Bottle @ FOneFan. Slightly hazy golden with medium white head, Flavour is malt, sweet, bitter, grass and hops.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are crisp clean hops, citrus and malt.

Bottle from Malt & Vine. Pours hazy gold with a creamy/bubbly white head. Aroma is pretty much noble hop, but theres a touch of citrus. Medium body. Flavor is ? Its not exactly bready, its pretty floral/grassy. Its slightly sweet, but the noble bitter renders that into the ground. Then it lets go wtih floral. And it is dry. This stuff drinks like ale. Move over Czechs!

Vibrant gold,straw colour. Big fluffy white head with good retention. 

Hoppy nose, passionfruit, lemon, white grape, grassiness. Very fresh, clean and tasty aroma.

Tropical hop flavours, soft maltiness, grainy bready. Strong bitterness, crisp dry finish. Beautiful balance of flavours. Very drinkable. Medium body with high carbonation.  

Absolutely beautiful beer. My favourite NZ pilsner. Great balance and very drinkable.

Bottle (BB Sep 2010).

Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy medium to dark yellow, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs), with notes of orange, honey, dried mango.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation.

Light lagers and pilsners are one of the most consistently underappreciated styles by beer geeks. Such appears to be the case here as well, because this is a wonderfully vibrant example of the style. Although, its fair to say that my experience may be quite different from a sample obtained at the source; this thing is seven months beyond the BB date, after all. For this style, normally that would yield a dull sample at best.  But this is anything but dull. Whereas this may have been more brightly hoppy when fresh, the bottle conditioning is presumably responsible for producing some delightful tropical esters. Not that such notes are all that typical for the style, but theyre certainly welcome. Would love to try this fresh. Props once again to Shelton for bringing another (apparently) great brewery stateside.

bread, bubblegum, medium bitterness, lightly sour, paper napkin, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, golden, hazy, frothy then minimal head.
Those were the prompt words, not sure where to put this. It initially smells like a bog-standard lager but has a bit more depth and artesian well feel to it. Well-made beer, but not my favourite style.

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Strong grassy and perfumed notes. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter wonderfull finish. Oily palate. More IPA ish than Boh. Pilsner.

Not quite sure how to describe this other than very tasty. Possibly one of the best balanced and tasteful pilsners Ive had. The one draw back is to the aroma which smells like a skunky bitter IPA . Other than that, it has very good balance with an evolving taste.

Flaske 33 cl. Dyb gylden med lidt diset krop, med et stort tæt vevarende hovede. Fantastisk humle aroma, med noter af tropiske frugter og svag citrus. Smagen er let bitter af humle. Fyldig mund og lang afbalenceret medium bitter finish
Clean malt nice hop, balancing to the bitter side.... 75 character minimum......
Its pretty hard to find clean, balanced pilsners. This one is perfect, my new #1 for the category. Sampled only in New Zealand several different times.

Sampled on 10/1/2010. This pilsner pours a slightly hazy medium orange gold color from a 33cl bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is cereal, grain and floral hops. A medium bodied pilsner. The malts are cereal and grainy. The hops are floral and slightly spicy. Decent carbonation. Nice balance. Finishes a little sweet, and a little bit off that sharp pilsner bite, but very drinkable. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and sweet. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
330ml bottle. Full creamy beige head that looks good sitting atop the bright amber base. Aromas of passionfruit, sweet and tart at the same time. Smooth dry flavour with that same sweet tartness.

Pours pale gold into a shaker. Bright white head quickly recedes leaving spot lacing. Skunky bread and resin aromas. Crisp sweet skunkwater with a lasting bitter Nelson finish. This just appeared on the East coast and its skunked, so perhaps the abv is a little low for a journey across the world...perhaps they make and ipa???

Bottle poured a hazy gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of bread, citrus and a hint of honey. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, straw and spicy hops with a crisp dry moderatly bitter finish.

Great caramel malt aroma. Very clean and complex. Just the right amount of spicy saaz hop aroma. Slightly hazy, straw gold, long standing frothy white head, noticeable carbonation and nice lacing. Taste is a nice sweet caramel malt with medium spicy saaz bitterness. Sweet malt up front with a quick blast of bitterness that lasts into a nice long and well balanced finish. Really a delicious beer.

Pours light golden with a thin well maintained white head. notes of sweet biscuit, pale malt, bright floral hops, lightly bitter herbs. medium bodied with light hop resin and moderate carbonation. I really enjoyed this one, the hops are quite nice.
Clear golden yellow pour, white head.  Light bread, malt, hay, herbal hops.  Very refreshing and drinkable, nice pilsener.
33cl bottle.  Hazy amber body topped by large white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, skunk, some lemon, light bread.  Taste is medium sweet, grass/skunk, light peach.  Licht body, chalk, some resin.
Bottle. Pours gold with a white head. Grainy malty aroma with spicy/floral hops. Well balanced flavor with earthy/floral hops and pale malts. Pretty good, and I bet way better fresh.

330 ml bottle

Aroma: very faint

Appearance: Hazy pale gold. Thin head with adequate lacing

Taste: medium bitterness no trace of sourness or sweetness.

Palate: thin to medium body faintly creamy, soft carbonation and a short bitter finish.

Overall: Labeled as a Bohemian pilsner but it comes across as a medium strength pale ale.

Bottled. A golden beer with a huge off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw, minerals, and malt, leading to a quite bitter finish. A nice pilsner interpretation.
Love this beer. A great take on a pilsner, and well executed. Nicely hoppy, clean flavours, just well made. Nuff said.

Looks exactly how a pilsner should, nice white foamy head.  Very hoppy on the nose, some malt, smells appetising.  Very well balance on the palate, superb feel, great backbone.  Great local pilsner, one of the best for me. Forgot to ad, nice pleasant dry finish, not overly bitter!

UPDATED: APR 1, 2013 Gold, just slightly hazy. A finger or so of bright white head. Some bread and lots of floral hops on the nose. Slightly earthy. Creamy mouthfeel. Restrained malts, lots of citrus. Finish is a little short - its bitter, but insubstantial. Fresh and lovely. [3.7]Bottle. Very pale gold with a very white head that lasts pretty well. Floral, light bread, bright lemon. Light-bodied, fairly high carbonation. Light bready malt, firm bitterness with lemons and some pepper. Well inside the fine Kiwi lager camp.

Vibrant gold pour with a large but quickly fading head that leaves lot of lacing.
Lots of grassy saaz in the aroma, with spicy and subtle sweet floral, grape and passionfruit notes.
Classic pilsener taste with light bready and grainy malt. Not much hops flavour, but a full-on metallic bitterness hits you in the face.
Light body, moderately high carbonation - good for the style.

Draft at Arrow Brewing Company in Arrowtown; guest tap in October 2009.  Pours a clear pale gold with a massive white head.  Malty aroma with hops, grain, citrus, and wheat.  Flavor is also malty and is more of the same.  Light bodied, crisp from the active carbonation.  Very good for the style.

Large frothy head hazy gold pour aroma strong hop fruity,citrus lemon grapefruit very smooth nice bitter,has a decent fizz,corn malt like sweetness,finish good hop and malt mix a fair effort by Tuatara.

Nice, clear, golden body with lasting white head that left lacing down the glass, probably the best feature. Grainy malty taste, a touch on the sweet side, some hops on the nose though not enough same with the taste.

330ml bottle, pours a light golden colour with a very subtle green tinge,  bubbly head, nice grassy resinous hops aroma which develops gold kiwifruit, passion fruit, paw paw, and lemon aromas as the beer warms slightly. Lots of hops bitterness on the palate which lingers in the aftertaste,  Overall a very satisfying beer
Pours a great golden colour, superb hop aroma, tastes very kiwi hops with lots of citrus tones with even malt tones  a great kiwi pils

This has just replaced Emersons Pilsner as my "go to" Pils. Its certainly far more faithful to the style. The only slight issue is a tropical note to the hopping which seems out of place in a Pilsner. Still a delicious beer though, and one I will be drinking much more of.
Draught. Pours clear golden with a lively white head. Sweet malt, grass, citrus and spice. Its very clean and crisp mouthfeel and good carbonation. Another good example of the Pils style in NZ.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 God how i love kiwi pilsners! This is no exception. Pours deep golden body with a nice white head. Nose has loads of tropical and citruss fruits with an underlying grassy, spicy hop character. Palate is more or less the same, pils malt adds a fraction of sweetness before hops take charge to deliver a spicy/tangy finish. Manages to maintain clean and crisp despite the overt fruitiness.

Enjoyed over a fantastic meal at Two Chefs in Dunedin with my wife. Bright clear golden, nice carbonation, big white bubbly head leaving long lacy strands. Grassy, floral, slightly skunky, lovely euro hop aroma. Clean pale malts, slightly sweet, slightly lemony, with a nice crisp bitter hop finish. A true pilsner.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Aroma is nice and hoppy with sweet malt, coriander and passionfruit. 
A nice citrus zest bitterness, tastes of herbs, orange peel and some ginger.
Unfortunately, tasted very alcoholic to me! Oh well, maybe a bad day. 
Good overall.

Pours golden, white bubbly head. Like a pilsner. Aroma is very hoppy - floral, passionfruit. Quite malty. Flavour is very much bitter, full of hops - very floral. Fruity at the same time, mainly passionfruit, but also very malty which balances quite nicely. The finish is malty and bitter, and quite long. Very nice.
Bottle at the Twisted Hop in Christchurch 01.05.09. Pours clear gold, white head. Aroma is hoppy, earthy, malty. Flavor is the same and peaty, and you all know how I feel about peat.
Gorgeous summer beer tasted at the malthouse full of zesty fruit an refreshing bitterness

Pours (from tap) with beautiful head that coverts into great belgium lace. Nothing much on the nose but the flavours are great, ha an interesting nuttiness! Its crisp and refreshing with a good finishing bitterness that is drying and invites further imbibing. Another great pilsner from an NZ brewery!

Fruity hop aroma - berries and passionfruit. Light, white head and clear, straw colour. passionfuit, melon and berry flavours dominate, but with the malt background just coming through to balance the hop flavour. A firm bitterness to finish, with lingering berries and a little grassy after-taste. Very drinkable.

Draught, compliments to the Malthouse (in Wellington), a clear gold with a white head. A light, hardly detectable aroma. A creamy palate which becomes more hoppier and drier through the finish. Sounds like the bottle has much more character.

(Bottle 33 cl) Clear, deep golden with a dense, white head leaving some lacework. Fresh aroma of flowers and a little citrus. Medium in body with a solid and fairly sweet malt base but primarily this is dominated by the great aroma hops. Subdued bitterness. This is almost like fluid candy. 110208
Bottle 33cl. Golden and slightly hazy body wih a large dense head. Lots of hops in the nose. Lots op hops in the flavour with a good bitter aftertaste.

converted some mainstream swillers.
 
We did a play off between glass flagon 
tuatara pilsner and bottled 
 
Consensus was glass flagons from regional wines and spirits were surpreme.

Food we had fresh mussels steamed  on a weber 57cm kettle using manuka hot direct heat  in a 40 cm steel pan     oil   garlic ginger onion hot chilli  johnathans spices indian mix  tuatara pilsner to steam  lid down   coconut cream  fish sauce  coriander  lemon  + zest and a crusty breads to mop out of the pan

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 Wow - This beer is like the proverbial mountain stream. Fresh. I have had this beer many times but not as Fresh as this one. Not only is it fresh but also has many layers. I am actually quite stunned as I was expecting quite less. 
Citrus and berry hop aroma, but also sweet like passion fruit with a hint of Pinot Gris. A very balanced body with clean crisp bitterness and a lingering hop flavour same as the aroma. 
I would be surprised if the flavour was really coming solely from Czech hops though and suspect that NZ Saaz B and D have been slipped in there at some stage... Still a fine drop!
This is about the sexiest pilsner being brewed in New Zealand. Creamy head and aftertaste, saaz hops.... forgive me, Im getting emotional.

Light golden colour, good creamy white head the settles to a fine creamy lace. Nice hop aroma, fresh grass, citrusy.
Light mouthfeel. Good bitterness. Malt was not too sweet true for German Pilsner. An excellent beer tasted in the town it was brewed.

Yellow gold in colour, very clear, very macro looking. Uneventful bouquet, perhaps sweet resiny hops is the most dominant feature  albeit in a faint, elegant fashion. Shines more brightly in the mouth with sweet, almost thick hop flavour and a touch of malt sweetness. Quaffable summer style.
Pale golden color. Light head, saaz hops hits the nose. Light bodied, nice hop bitterness in mouth. Straight forward, but well made Pils, with moderate bitter finish.  I love NZ pils

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2017 Draught at The Malthouse, Wellington.  Clear pale yellow. Dry with plenty of grassy hops. Its light bodied with gentle rounded mouthfeel. Theres notes of lemon and a bitterness that grows and grows. Only needs to be more crisp to achieve greatness.

Tasted 31/12/2005.  330ml bottle from Bisque on Bolton, New Years Eve dinner.
Pale gold, slight haze, with a white, lingering, head and a light carbonation.  Superbly fresh nose that holds its own through the entire glass.  A real treat of passionfruit, lemon, spicey floral notes and hints of the fruity honey-like aroma of a german riesling.  Up there with Emersons Pilsner, though a touch more subtle.  Good flavour, though just a touch light in the juicy sweet pilsner malt department, shows though a decent spicey hop flavour and a shortish bitter finish. Crisp and fresh.  Smooth carbonation and light-medium weight.  More malt sweetness showing through and this would be one of the best. Another lovely beer from Carl Vastas under-rated Reikiorangi brewery.

On tap.  Almost colourless beer with a non-existant head.  Aroma is decently hoppy (Saaz) but very low on the malt side.  A bit citrusy aroma as well.  Decently hoppy flavour with some light spiciness and a bit of pale malt.  Slight appley flavour.

My appreciation of Kiwi pilseners is somewhat affected by the brilliance of Emersons. This one is a fine specimen though, and it reminds me more of the Budvar (stick Czechvar up your fundiment A-B) in that I find this softer and more subtle in hop profile. A great looking beer with a typically expected golden hue and clean head. The beer is well balanced and has all of the qualities of a beer that is difficult to get right. NZ water goes a long way to helping with the subtlety and quality of the beer. Ta Beer_Ledgend.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: UPDATED: JAN 22, 2005 Quite pale for a Czech-style Pils without the golden colour from the long boil. OK head. Great aroma - very fresh, juicy malt with more fresh passionfruity hops and perhaps a bit of wort. Really nice, and like something but I cant think what it is. Initially tastes just like it smells - really fruity and juicy - but kind of falls away mid-palate, lacking the firm body of many Czech Pils. Finishes pretty strong, not overly bitter but has a nice crisp hoppiness to it. Slight astringency at the end. Thanks to beer_ledgend for this one!
Nice clear yellow straw colour, big hoppy flavour,, sweet aroma of hops, lovley big bitter taste. One could go on about NZ Saaz hops but this is a tradional pilsner style.

just i was thinking i hated nz hops, i tasted them in a beer where they actually worked. amazing aroma of passionfruit and taste of passionfruit seeds. some creeping bitterness. soft and subtle, a few other flavours appear on the periphery - applesauce, mango icecream. a real delight

original and well made stuff. the aroma is pure NZ saazy stuff, passiona to the max. good czech style malty, firm malt body without the graininess that you sometimes get with german ones, along with slight munich nuttiness. big flowery hop flavour, passionfruity at first, then getting more peppery and bitter as you swallow. the soft maltiness keeps up with the hops all the way through the finish.
Deep golden colour.  Good bitter, earthy hop flavour.  After Emersons, probably the best pils in NZ.
